CurrentPositioning.title: Current Positioning
CurrentPositioning.description:
Investment Asset Leverage = 463% vs. 352% at 12/31

Surveyor (24% up from 23% at 12/31) 
-36 PMs, 192 investment professional
-Strong performance during earnings
-Underperformance attributable to sub-industry tilts (especially within industrials)
-Also attribute underperformance of shorts to shift from active to passive ($1 trillion in last two years), causing more of a lag in prices to reflect fundamentals in addition being more cognizant of short exposure held in ETFs

Global Equities (21% ,down from 23% at 12/31)
-29 PMs, 165 investment professionals 
-Witnessed similar observations as Surveyor, which negatively affected performance (i.e., active to passive shift)

Aptigon (6% up from 1% at 12/31)
-21 PMs, 91 investment professionals
-Starting to ramp up risk, expect to grow considerably throughout 2017

Global Fixed Income (25% up from 18% at 12/31)
-38 PMs / 17 pods / 5 units
-Risk remains diversified across numerous risk takers

Commodities (7% down from 17% at 12/31)
-70 investment professionals
-Hired new head from Macquarie (Sebastian Barrack) - previously co-headed metals, mining, and ags at Macquarie- was based in Australia, which provides Asian expertise - will move to Chicago. 

Credit (9% up from 7% at 12/31)
-25 investment professionals
-Remain focused on liquid opportunities

Quant (4% down from 8% at 12/31)
-85 investment professionals
- Jonathan Graham (head of quantitative strategies) is stepping down - his departure was voluntary / not performance related, and he apparently needed a break and is leaving the industry. James Yeh (started at Citadel in 1993, focused on stat arb, high frequency trading, options market making) rejoined Citadel last year and will become the new head of quantitative strategies. Ken expects this to be a seamless transition.

CurrentPositioning.title: Current Positioning
CurrentPositioning.description:
Investment Asset Leverage = 433% vs. 352% at 12/31
Fund AUM = $17.3 billion vs. $16.8 billion at 12/31 

Surveyor (24% up from 23% at 12/31) 
-36 PMs, 175 investment professional (Sizable increase in PM teams during 2017 through a combination of hiring and organic growth / promoting within.)
-Strong performance during earnings
-Underperformance attributable to sub-industry tils (especially within industrials)
-Also attribute underperformance of shorts to shift from active to passive ($1 trillion in last two years), causing more of a lag in prices to reflect fundamentals in addition being more cognizant of short exposure held in ETFs

Global Equities (19% down from 23% at 12/31)
-29 PMs, 182 investment professionals 
-Stainton plans to increase total number of teams to 35-40 ? he continues to integrate his changes to the Surveyor platform
-Witnessed similar observations as Surveyor, which negatively affected performance (i.e., active to passive shift)

Aptigon (5% up from 1% at 12/31)
-23 PMs (18 actively taking risk), 62 investment professionals
-Have fired three PMs to date, which account for the majority of negative returns
-Schimel hired a head of research, which will ensure proper development of analysts and recognition of top performers (i.e., promotion to PM)
-Starting to ramp up risk, expect to grow considerably throughout 2017, but will not ramp aggressively

Global Fixed Income (26% up from 18% at 12/31)
-38 PMs / 17 pods / 5 units
-Risk remains diversified across numerous risk takers
-Positioning is more micro in nature with active trading opposed to top down macro bets

Commodities (12% down from 17% at 12/31)
-70 investment professionals
-Hired new head from Macquarie (Sebastian Barrack) - previously co-headed metals, mining, and ags at Macquarie- was based in Australia, which provides Asian expertise - will move to Chicago. 

Credit (7% unchanged)
-25 investment professionals
-Fundamental ($35M), converts ($22M), and liquid stressed ($11M) drove gains
-Remain focused on liquid opportunities

Quant (6% down from 8% at 12/31)
-85 investment professionals
- Jonathan Graham (head of quantitative strategies) is stepping down - his departure was voluntary / not performance related, and he apparently needed a break and is leaving the industry. James Yeh (started at Citadel in 1993, focused on stat arb, high frequency trading, options market making) rejoined Citadel last year and will become the new head of quantitative strategies. Ken expects this to be a seamless transition.
-Quant FICC strategies have struggled from a performance perspective.
-Equity models have demonstrated greater effectiveness, but have capacity constraints.

Event (0% risk currently)
-Eric Felder (ex-Magnetar) has started building out his team. He plans to invest across equity and credit asset classes. Unlikely to have risk on in 2017, but once exposure grows the focus will consist mainly of liquid opportunities

Commodities (15% down from 17% at 12/31)
